textBeforeTable: Tooth emergence chart Teeth generally appear from the age of around 6 months, but there are wild variations with some babies born with teeth and others not cutting a tooth until after their first birthday. Teeth, and in particular babies teeth, are an endless source of discussion and debate. "Has yours cut a tooth yet?" "Oh, look how red her cheeks are - I'm sure she's teething" And that famous excuse for a sleepless night with baby is "She must be getting more teeth". textAfterTable: When to expect teeth to appear  Just as a watched pot of water seems never to boil, watching for teeth seems only to ensure they won't appear. The minute you forget about teething, your baby will suddenly have a shiny white pearl on a gum and - voila - teething has occurred.  Tooth buds are in place at birth and babies typically have 20 primary (baby) teeth, which usually begin to emerge any time between 3 months of age until 12 months (though most likely 6 months) to accomodate the need to eat solid foods. The two bottom teeth are the first to arrive - although this doesn't happen in all cases. Next, the top two front teeth, followed by the two teeth on either side. After that, other teeth slowly begin to fill in, usually in pairs - one each side of the upper or lower jaw - until all 20 teeth (10 in the upper jaw and 10 in the lower jaw) have come in by the time she is two and a half or three years old. Types of teeth Incisor On the dental chart, incisors are located in the front of the mouth and have sharp, thin edges for cutting. Their use is to incise or cut food and their appearance tends to be shovel-shaped. Cuspid Cuspids, also referred to as canines, are at the angles of the mouth on the tooth chart. Each has a
